{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} '''Joke theft''' is the act of performing and taking credit for comic material written by another person without their [[consent]]. This is a form of [[plagiarism]] and can, in some cases, be [[copyright infringement]]. ==History== ===Vaudeville years=== In [[music hall]]s and [[vaudeville]], it was common for performers to "borrow" material. According to [[Milton Berle]], [[etiquette]] only required that "the borrower add to the joke and make it his own".<ref name="Berle1989xxiii">Berle, Milton (1989) ''Private joke file'', ''Introduction'', p.xxiii quotation: {{quotation|Of course, in the days of vaudeville, it wasn't uncommon for a performer to "borrow" a joke from another performer. Etiquette demanded only that the borrower add to the joke and make it his own. Bert Williams, a star of the Ziegfeld Follies, pilfered a story about fish and added enough laughs to turn it into a classic fifteen-minute routine. Naturally, that routine happens to be in my file.}}</ref> At the time there were few chances that a performer from one area would meet one from another and a single twenty-minute set could sustain a comic for a decade. Most jokes at the time were one-liners and there was little in the way of proof of a joke's origin, but the value of each joke was immeasurable to a comedian.<ref name="radartake">{{cite web |url =http://www.radaronline.com/from-the-magazine/2007/02/take_the_funny_and_run_1.php |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070217031356/http://www.radaronline.com/from-the-magazine/2007/02/take_the_funny_and_run_1.php |title=Take the Funny and Run |date=2007-02-14 |accessdate = 2010-01-12 |author = Larry Getlen |archivedate = 2007-02-17 |work = [[Radar (magazine)|Radar]] }}</ref> Berle and [[Bob Hope]] had a long-standing feud due to Hope's accusation that Milton Berle had stolen some of his jokes.<ref name="radartake" /> Berle never disputed the claim, but instead embraced the title "The Thief of Bad Gag".
Even the most famous of comics have found themselves, knowingly or unknowingly, stealing material. [[Bill Cosby]] admitted to stealing a joke by George Carlin involving an uneducated football player doing a television commercial. Cosby said that what makes the routine his own is the surreal phrase "little tiny hairs".<ref name="funny">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-et-joketheft24jul24,1,6252669,full.story?coll=la-headlines-california&ctrack=5&cset=true |title=Funny, that was my joke |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |last=Welkos |first=Robert W. |date=2007-07-24 |accessdate=2009-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221013725/http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-et-joketheft24jul24%2C1%2C6252669%2Cfull.story?coll=la-headlines-california&ctrack=5&cset=true |archivedate=21 December 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite video|people=Cosby, Bill|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AikgyewBn8k|title=Late Show with David Letterman – Bill Cosby's Race Against George Carlin|publisher=[[CBS]]|medium=TV|date=2009-06-01|accessdate=2009-11-27}}</ref> Many years later, [[Carlos Mencia]] performed a bit about athletes and their parents that hearkened back to a Cosby bit from his album ''[[Bill Cosby: Himself]]''.
===1970s=== In the 1970s, joke theft became more prominent with the boom in popularity of comedy. The 1980s and 1990s saw the popularity of [[stand-up comedy]] continue to increase. The advent of pay-cable networks afforded comics the opportunity to perform their routines unfettered. With this came a new type of joke theft in which the first comic to tell a stolen joke on some sort of media became the one associated with the joke.
[[Robin Williams]] was accused of stealing material from another comic. [[David Brenner]] claims that he confronted Williams personally and threatened him with bodily harm if he heard Williams utter another one of his jokes.<ref name="Comedy at the Edge">{{cite book | title=Comedy at the Edge | author=Richard Zoglin | year=2008 | publisher=Bloomsbury USA | isbn=978-1582346243}}</ref>
===1990s=== For many years, [[Denis Leary]] had been friends with fellow comedian [[Bill Hicks]]. However, when Hicks heard Leary's 1993 album ''No Cure For Cancer'', he felt Leary had stolen his act and material, and the friendship ended abruptly as a result.<ref name="evolutionBook">{{cite book | title=Bill Hicks: Agent of Evolution | author=[[Kevin Booth]] and Michael Bertin | year=2005 | publisher=Harper Collins | isbn=0-00-719829-9}}</ref> At least three stand-up comedians have gone on the record stating they believe Leary stole not just some of Hicks' material but his persona and attitude.<ref name="evolutionBook" /><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.joerogan.net/main.php?archives=1&article=44170 |title=Carlos Mencia is a weak minded joke thief | author=Joe Rogan | publisher=JoeRogan.net | year=2005 | accessdate=2006-10-28 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051218140900/http://www.joerogan.net/main.php?archives=1&article=44170 |archivedate = 2005-12-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite interview |title=Joe Rogan answers 20 Questions | last=Rogan | first=Joe | work=Playboy Magazine |date=October 2003}}</ref><ref name="hicksfaq">{{cite web | url=http://www.billhicks.com/darktimes/other/darktimes20/faq/faq.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060320081614/http://www.billhicks.com/darktimes/other/darktimes20/faq/faq.html | title=Dark Times: Bill Hicks: Frequently Asked Questions | author=Tim McIntire | year=1998 | publisher=BillHicks.com | archivedate=2006-03-20 | accessdate=2006-10-28}}</ref> As a result of this, it is claimed that after Hicks' death from [[pancreatic cancer]], an industry joke began to circulate about Leary's transformation and subsequent success (roughly; "Question: Why is Denis Leary a star while Bill Hicks is unknown? Answer: Because there's no cure for cancer").<ref name="hicksfaq" />
In a 2008 appearance on ''The Opie and Anthony Show'', comedian [[Louis C.K.]] claimed that Leary stole his "I'm an asshole" routine, which was then expanded upon and turned into a hit song by Leary.<ref name="Berle1989xxiii"/> On a later episode of the same show, Leary challenged this assertion by claiming that he (Leary) co-wrote the song with Chris Phillips.<ref name="radartake"/>
In his memoir ''[[Gasping for Airtime]]'', [[Jay Mohr]] admitted that he lifted an entire routine from [[Rick Shapiro]]'s act for a 1995 ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch. He stated that Shapiro sued the show and was financially compensated, but Shapiro later disputed that he received any compensation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mohr|first1=Jay|title=Gasping for Airtime: Two Years in the Trenches of Saturday Night Live|date=2004|publisher=Hyperion Books|isbn=1401300065|pages=276–9}}</ref>
===2000s and 2010s=== Louis C.K. has maintained a relatively quiet rivalry with [[Dane Cook]] over three bits on Cook's album, ''Retaliation'', that allegedly bear some resemblance to three bits on C.K.'s album ''Live in Houston''. C.K. and Cook portray this rivalry with comedy and sincerity in an episode of C.K.'s series ''[[Louie (U.S. TV series)|Louie]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://thecomicscomic.com/2011/08/05/dane-cook-confronts-louis-ck-in-an-honest-way-about-joke-theft-read-the-transcript-watch-the-video/ | title = Dane Cook confronts Louis CK in an honest way about joke theft. Read the transcript, watch the video! | accessdate = 2011-12-12 | author = Sean L. McCarthy | date = 2011-10-26 | publisher = The Comic's Comic. }}</ref>
[[George Lopez]] has accused Carlos Mencia of plagiarizing his material and claimed that the two once had a physical altercation over the alleged plagiarism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.ucdadvocate.com/media/storage/paper538/news/2007/05/02/BonusBytes/Is.Carlos.Mencia.A.Thief-2891990.shtml |author=Goldyn, Debra |title=Is Carlos Mencia a thief? |work=Advocate |publisher=[[University of Colorado at Denver]] |date=2007-05-02 |accessdate=2007-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007092111/http://media.www.ucdadvocate.com/media/storage/paper538/news/2007/05/02/BonusBytes/Is.Carlos.Mencia.A.Thief-2891990.shtml |archivedate=7 October 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> However, fellow comedian Ted Sarnowski countered this claim and stated that it was he, not Lopez, who had originally penned the joke and that he had given Mencia permission to use it when he discovered that Lopez had stolen it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacitybeat.com/cms/story/detail/?id=5264&IssueNum=199|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216161529/http://www.lacitybeat.com/cms/story/detail/?id=5264&IssueNum=199|archivedate=16 February 2008|author=Kozlowski, Carl|title=Carlos Mencia Just Said That|work=|publisher=Los Angeles CityBeat|date=2007-03-29|accessdate=2007-07-14}}</ref>
In 2010, Italian comic and satirist [[Daniele Luttazzi]] was accused by anonymous bloggers of having plagiarised many jokes from comedians such as [[George Carlin]], [[Mitch Hedberg]], [[Eddie Izzard]], [[Chris Rock]], [[Bill Hicks]] and [[Robert Schimmel]].<ref name="rep_lut">{{cite web |url=http://www.repubblica.it/spettacoli-e-cultura/2010/06/09/news/luttazzi-secopia-4703064/ |title=La Rete contro Luttazzi: "Copia" I dubbi dei fan, il tam-tam cresce – Repubblica.it |accessdate=2010-06-09 |work=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.unita.it/media/Politica/Luttazzi_copia_Parte_1_1395.html |title=Luttazzi copia – Parte 1 |accessdate=2010-06-11 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612084318/http://video.unita.it/media/Politica/Luttazzi_copia_Parte_1_1395.html |archivedate=12 June 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> However, in a personal blog entry published five years prior, Luttazzi himself offered his blog readers a prize if they were able to identify a "nugget" (i.e. a reference to a famous joke), calling the game a "treasure hunt".<ref name="blo_lut">{{cite web |url=http://danieleluttazzi.blogspot.com/|title=Caccia al tesoro|author=Luttazzi, Daniele}}</ref> He says he adds references to famous comedians' jokes to his work as a defense against the million-euro lawsuits he has to face because of his satire. (In March 2012, Luttazzi won a legal battle against [[La7]] broadcasting company, which in 2007 abruptly closed his late show "Decameron", accusing him, among other charges, of plagiarism from Bill Hicks. Sentence: It was original satire, not plagiarism. Luttazzi got 1 million 2 hundred thousand euros as compensation.) <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.corriere.it/spettacoli/12_marzo_10/satira-tv-luttazzi-vince-causa-contro-la-7-franco_69183226-6a83-11e1-8b63-010bde402ef9.shtml|title=Luttazzi vince la causa contro La7|date=10 March 2012|accessdate=10 March 2012|publisher=corriere.it}}</ref> He calls this ruse "the [[Lenny Bruce]] trick" (named for the comic of same name). Luttazzi asserts that the jokes he references are not "plagiarized" but "calqued", which is a fair use of original material. In 2014, an academic paper explained why Luttazzi's jokes are his own and not "plagiarised" ones.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Caimotto|first1=M.Cristina|title=Transcreating a New Kind of Humor: the case of Daniele Luttazzi|url=http://www.cultusjournal.com/index.php/archive/16-issue-2014-v-7-transcreation-and-the-professions|website=cultusjournal.com|accessdate=5 August 2017}}</ref>
In 2011, ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]'' contestant Jordan Paris presented an act of stand-up comedy and quickly proceeded to the semi-finals.<ref>Waters, G 2011, '[http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/comedy/australias-got-plagiarism-ripoff-comic-exposed-20110526-1f50v.html Australia's Got Plagiarism: rip-off comic exposed]', ''Brisbane Times'' 26 May 2011</ref> However, it was later revealed that he had plagiarised his jokes from comedians [[Lee Mack]] and [[Geoff Keith]]. The television network gave him a chance to redeem himself and allowed him to compete in the semi-finals using his own material. Paris' effort this time was self-deprecating, joking about his plagiarism and his large teeth. The first joke went well, but the rest went downhill. It was later found out that the joke that went well – "I just sacked my two writers – Copy and Paste" – had been done in 2009 by comedian [[Jeffrey Ross]], about [[Brad Garrett]], at a roast of [[Joan Rivers]]. Ross had said, "This guy has two writers, their names are Cut and Paste."<ref>Nancarrow, D 2011, [http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/oops-he-did-it-again-ripoff-comic-plunders-joke-about-plagiarism-20110629-1gq1d.html 'Oops. He did it again: Rip-off comic plunders joke about plagiarism'], ''Brisbane Times'', 29 June 2010,</ref>
In January 2012, blogger and comedian Troy Holm was ridiculed on the [[social networking]] site Facebook<ref name="facebook1">{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/pages/Occupy-Troy-Holm/217011661714006 |title=Occupy Troy Holm |publisher=Facebook |accessdate=2012-07-11}}</ref> for stealing jokes and stories from comedian [[Doug Stanhope]] and posting them to his blog from 2010, [[plagiarism|claiming them as his own work]],<ref>[https://archive.is/20120701002315/http://exmypa.blogspot.com/2010/07/working-hardprisondrug-war.html ]</ref> including Stanhope's "Fuck someone uglier than you" routine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://exmypa.blogspot.com/2010/07/fuck-someone-ugly.html |accessdate=3 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103154727/http://exmypa.blogspot.com/2010/07/fuck-someone-ugly.html |archivedate=3 January 2012 |title=Fuck Someone Ugly|date=July 13, 2010}}</ref> which was found on Stanhope's ''Acid Bootleg''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Doug+Stanhope/ACID+Bootleg |title=ACID Bootleg – Doug Stanhope – Listen and discover music at |publisher=Last.fm |date=2012-06-26 |accessdate=2012-07-11}}</ref> Troy Holm also plagiarized Stanhope's story of an encounter with a transsexual prostitute<ref>[[Sicko (album)]]</ref> nearly verbatim, substituting himself as Stanhope, and changing a few small details,<ref>[https://archive.is/20120701001921/http://exmypa.blogspot.com/2010/06/hooker-story-and-dmt-story.html ]</ref> causing a backlash from Stanhope's fans. This catapulted Troy Holm into an internet icon which started the "Occupy Troy Holm" Movement.<ref name="facebook1"/> Stanhope commented on the Occupy Troy Holm Facebook page that "To the few people who seem to think this is overboard...and it is...I don't think that you know the levels to which this guy has been ripping me off. He didn't take a tit-fuck joke and use it as a status update. He's been living my entire life as though it was his, changing some names and then promoting with twitters... Look at his site and most the entirety of it is me, including the comments where he uses my stuff to pass as his own conversation. And on Twitter. So who is he ripping off for that stuff that ''isn't'' mine?"<ref name="facebook1"/>
==In other media== Joke theft is not limited to stand-up comedy. Often jokes in film and television shows are taken from comics or even other media. [[Dick Cavett]] wrote about joke theft in his autobiography. He'd written a bit about eating Chinese-German food and, an hour later, being hungry for power. After a few days of performing the bit, he discovered a column by [[Earl Wilson (columnist)|Earl Wilson]] which attributed the joke to [[Rip Taylor]]. However, after calling Taylor to ask him to stop using the bit, he discovered that not only had Taylor never performed the bit, he had never even heard it and laughed heartily at the joke's humor. It was then that Cavett discovered that some journalists often falsely attribute jokes to the wrong comics.<ref>{{cite book | title=Cavett | author=Dick Cavett, Christopher Porterfield | year=1974| publisher=Harcourt Brace Jovanovich |pages=227–228| isbn=978-0151161300}}</ref>
Cavett and [[Woody Allen]] often cited to each other the many instances of their jokes appearing in television shows without their permission, sometimes even falsely attributed to each other. Allen's jokes, when he still lacked access to television, were regularly stolen by top mainstream shows ''[[The Red Skelton Show]]'' and ''[[Laugh In]]''.<ref name="Cavett interview">{{cite web|url=http://www.sheckymagazine.com/cavett.htm |title=SHECKY! Interview: DICK CAVETT! |publisher=Sheckymagazine.com |accessdate=2012-07-11}} quotation: {{quotation|Woody's best lines would show up, while he was still confined to little Village clubs, on the Red Skelton show and that alleged entertainment, Laugh-In.}}</ref> This proved extremely painful to Allen.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
Several episodes of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', including "[[Missionary: Impossible]]", "[[Treehouse of Horror XIII]]" and "[[The Italian Bob]]" have poked fun at ''[[Family Guy]]'', implying that MacFarlane's show is guilty of stealing jokes and premises from the Simpsons. However, the producers of both shows have said that there is no serious feud between the two of them and their shows.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.avclub.com/content/node/47771 | title = Interview: Matt Groening | accessdate = 2006-12-12 | author = Nathan Rabin | date = 2006-04-26 | work = The A.V. Club | publisher = Onion Inc. | quote = The rivalry is very affectionate...}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://familyguy.tktv.net/news.html|title=''Family Guy'' Timeline at familyguy.tktv.net|quote=You know, it's funny. Matt Groening and I actually have a great relationship...}}</ref>
In 2017 the Australian television show host [[Grant Denyer]] was interviewed on the radio programme ''[[The Grill Team]]'', which is on [[2MMM]]. In the interview, ''The Grill Team''{{'}}s co-host [[Matty Johns]] told an amusing anecdote about introducing a child to the board game ''[[Test Match (board game)|Test Match]]''. Later that morning, Grant Denyer was interviewed on the radio programme ''[[The Kyle and Jackie O Show]]'', which is on [[KIIS 106.5]]. In that interview, he told the same anecdote about ''Test Match'', passing it off as his own.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://au.be.yahoo.com/entertainment/celebrity/a/34283262/grant-denyer-banned-from-triple-m-and-kiis-fm-radio-stations-for-stealing-story-yahoo7-be/#page1 | title = Grant Denyer Banned From Triple M and KIIS FM Radio Stations For Stealing Story | accessdate = 2017-01-28 | author = Leah Cohen | date = 2017-01-28 | work = Yahoo7Be | publisher = Yahoo!7}}</ref>
==Recourse and consequences== There is, historically, very little [[legal recourse]] taken in cases of joke theft. Some comics, however, have chosen to exact their own justice. [[W. C. Fields]] reportedly paid fifty dollars to have a thieving comic's legs broken.<ref name="radartake" />
"You have a better chance of stopping a serial killer than a serial thief in comedy," said comedian [[David Brenner]]. "If we could protect our jokes, I'd be a retired billionaire in Europe somewhere – and what I just said is original."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jul/24/entertainment/et-joketheft24|title=Funny, that was my joke|last=Welkos|first=Robert W.|date=2007-07-24|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-05-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
According to a 2018 study in the ''American Sociological Review'', "most instances of possible joke theft are ambiguous owing to the potential for simultaneous and coincidental discovery".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Reilly|first=Patrick|date=2018-08-17|title=No Laughter among Thieves: Authenticity and the Enforcement of Community Norms in Stand-Up Comedy|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0003122418791174|journal=American Sociological Review|language=en|pages=000312241879117|doi=10.1177/0003122418791174|issn=0003-1224}}</ref> The study argues:<ref name=":0" /><blockquote>"that accusations are not strongly coupled to jokes’ similarity, and enforcement depends mainly on the extent to which insiders view the comic in question as being authentic to the community. Comics who are oriented toward external rewards, have a track record of anti-social behavior, and exhibit lackluster on-stage craft are vulnerable to joke theft accusations even in borderline cases because those inauthentic characteristics are typical of transgressors. Vulnerability is greatest for comics who enjoy commercial success despite low peer esteem."</blockquote>

{{Infobox Museum |name = JRG Halad Museum |image = Halad image.jpg |imagesize = 250 |caption = |pushpin_map = |map_caption= |coordinates = {{coord|10.296973|123.902124|display=inline}} |established =2010 |dissolved = |location = [[Cebu City]], [[Philippines]] |type = [[Music]] Museum, [[Cultural heritage|Heritage]] Museum |visitors = |founder = Jose R. Gullas |director = |curator = |publictransit = |website = }}
'''JRG Halad Museum''' is a musically-themed museum in [[Cebu City]], [[Philippines]] that pays homage to the musical heritage of Cebu.<ref>[http://www.philstar.com/cebu-lifestyle/2014/03/20/1303068/jrg-halad-museum "JRG Halad Museum"]. ''The Freeman'', By Maria Eleanor E. Valeros March 20, 2014</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Revamped JRG Halad Museum opens to the public |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=693251&publicationSubCategoryId=51 |accessdate=27 June 2011 |newspaper=The Freeman |date=5 June 2011 }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Location== Located along V. Gullas St. (former Manalili) and D. Jakosalem St. [[Cebu City]], the old building of [[The Freeman Newspaper]] has been converted to a museum which houses Cebuano and Visayan musical treasures and memorabilia.
==History== Founded by Jose "Dodong" R. Gullas, the Halad Museum was inaugurated on January 12, 2010 and opened to the public on February 2, 2010.<ref>[http://208.184.76.175/Article.aspx?articleId=543137&publicationSubCategoryId=111]{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Piramide|first=Aven|title=Halad Museum from a different angle|url=http://www.philstar.com/freeman-opinion/699716/halad-museum-different-angle|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=26 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lao|first=Garry|title=Council lauds Gullas for Halad Museum|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=699005&publicationSubCategoryId=107|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=23 June 2011}}</ref>
With the founder's support, reviving works of long forgotten composers was achieved via concerts of an award-winning university-based choir, the UV Chorale<ref>{{cite news|title=2009: A great year for the UV Chorale|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=536169&publicationSubCategoryId=107|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=28 December 2009}}</ref> of which the first of the ''Halad'' concerts came about in 2007 wherein a group of composers were honored posthumously including [[Ben Zubiri]], composer of ''Matud Nila'',<ref>[{{cite news|title=Ben Zubiri's piano another addition to Kinaiyang Sugbuanon Museum|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=496461&publicationSubCategoryId=51|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=16 August 2009}}</ref> and Vicente Rubi, composer of [[Kasadya Ning Taknaa]]. This started the donations of family members of the honorees for the three Halad concerts (in 2007, 2008 and 2010) <ref>[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=50876]</ref> from lyric sheets to instruments, prompting the idea of a repository—a museum. Eventually, the founder was inspired to actively acquire other musical memorabilia, not just to keep the memory of the honorees alive, but also hopefully, to educate youngsters on how rich Cebu's musical heritage is.
''Halad'' means tribute or offering in the Cebuano language, as such, the museum is dedicated to the founder's parents, Don Vicente and Inday Pining Gullas, who founded the [[University of the Visayas]] in Cebu, Philippines.
In November 2010, expansion of the museum was carried out to make more room for the increasing collections held by the museum which includes memorabilia of Cebuano composers and artists in the 20th century, from musical instruments, lyric sheets to long-playing records.
The revamped and completed Halad Museum was opened to the public in June 13, 2011 with more musical pieces on exhibit.<ref>{{cite news|last=Duraliza|first=Debbie|title=Halad Museum now open to the public with more musical pieces on exhibit|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=695818&publicationSubCategoryId=51|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=13 June 2011}}</ref> The museum features three galleries dedicated to Cebuano music, ''kinaiyang Sugbuanon'' (Cebuano cultural traditions), and the founder's gallery.
==Mission-Vision== The JRG Halad Museum pays tribute to the enduring legacies of Cebuano cultural heritage as expressed through music.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dioko|first=Eladio|title=Halad - museum for the heart|url=http://www.philstar.com/freeman-opinion/698756/halad-museum-heart|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=23 June 2011}}</ref> Visitors experience Cebuano music, performing arts, cultural heritage and research exhibitions.
==Permanent Exhibits== The Halad Music Gallery displays composers from the 20th century who have produced well-known Cebuano songs, as well as artists who have earned international recognition for their talents.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sumacot|first=Nina|title=Cebuano culture gets boost with Gullas Halad Museum|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=540379&publicationSubCategoryId=107|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=13 January 2010}}</ref> Highlights include original music sheets and musical instruments played by the composers themselves and numerous awards and personal items from gowns to gadgets owned by the artists. Turntables and digital music stations are also available for visitors.
The musical memorabilia plus instruments occupy the main section of the museum, but with its recent expansion, it is now home to other interests. The ''Kinaiyang Sugbuanon'' section showcases the Cebuano traditions over time including life-cycle events, popular practices and expressions of religiosity in the different artworks depicted.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tomada|first=Nathalie|title=Museum, concert to mark "Kinaiyang Sugbuanon"|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=529927&publicationSubCategoryId=107|accessdate=27 June 2011|newspaper=The Freeman|date=6 December 2009}}</ref> Another gallery is devoted to the founder who pays tribute to the most influential people in his life, his parents and his living commitment to heritage preservation.
==Resolution==
On June 22, 2011, the Cebu City Council commended the museum founder, Jose R. Gullas, for his efforts to help preserve Cebu's musical and cultural heritage through the Halad Museum. A commendation was made through a resolution sponsored by Councilor Margarita Osmeña, chairperson of the Council’s committee on tourism and culture.

{{Infobox journal | title = Journal of Hindu Studies | cover = Journal_of_Hindu_Studies.gif | editor = Gavin Flood, Jessica Frazier, Rembert Lutjeharms | discipline = Hindu Studies | peer-reviewed = | former_names = | abbreviation = | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | country = | frequency = Triannual | history = 2008-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://jhs.oxfordjournals.org/ | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = 17564255 | OCLC = 301680132 | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 1756-4255 | eISSN = 1756-4263 }} The '''''Journal of Hindu Studies''''' is a triannual [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] established in 2008. It is published by [[Oxford University Press]] on behalf of the [[Oxford Centre for Hindu Studies]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.library.georgetown.edu/newjour/j/msg04880.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719201718/http://old.library.georgetown.edu/newjour/j/msg04880.html |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}</ref> It covers all aspects of [[Hindu studies]].
Of the three annual issues, one is guest-edited and one open for submissions. The third issue usually publishes conference and panel papers. The first two issues are on the same broad annual theme. Themes published to date include: Hermeneutics and Interpretation, Aesthetics and the Arts, and Reason and Rationality.
The disciplines represented in the journal include [[history]], [[philology]], [[literature]] and [[the arts]], [[philosophy]], [[anthropology]], [[sociology]], [[archaeology]], and [[religious studies]].
The [[Editor-in-chief|editors-in-chief]] are [[Gavin Flood]], [[Jessica Frazier]], and Rembert Lutjeharms.

| publisher = [[University of California Press]] on behalf of the [[American Musicological Society]] | country = United States | frequency = Triannually | history = 1948-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.ucpressjournals.com/journal.asp?j=jams | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = 00030139 | OCLC = 470176893 | LCCN = 50012713 | CODEN = | ISSN = 0003-0139 | eISSN = 1547-3848 | boxwidth = }} The '''''Journal of the American Musicological Society''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] and an official journal of the [[American Musicological Society]]. It is published by [[University of California Press]] and covers all aspects of [[musicology]].
The ''Journal of the American Musicological Society'' has been published three times a year since 1948. It was preceded by the annual '''''Bulletin of the American Musicological Society<!--redirected-->''''' (1936–1947) and the annual '''''Papers of the American Musicological Society<!--redirected-->''''' (1936–1941). Online versions of the journal and its predecessors are available at [[JSTOR]] and the University of California Press.

'''Leslie J. Hoppe, O.F.M.''' (born 22 September 1944) is a [[Roman catholic priest]] and [[Franciscan]] [[Old Testament]] scholar with a focus on [[Deuteronomy]] and Deuteronomic literature and is an expert in [[biblical studies]]. He is Carroll Stuhlmueller Distinguished Professor of Old Testament Studies at [[Catholic Theological Union]]<ref name=CTUprofile>{{cite web |title=Leslie J. Hoppe, OFM |url=https://ctu.edu/faculty/leslie-hoppe/ |website=Catholic Theological Union |publisher=Catholic Theological Union Faculty |accessdate=2 November 2018}}</ref> in Chicago and the general editor of the refereed theological journal [[Catholic Biblical Quarterly]].
Between 2015-2016, he served as President of the [[Catholic Biblical Association]] and has also served as the President of the [[Chicago Society of Biblical Research]] and was visting professor at [[Garrett-Evangelical Theological Seminary]], [[Studium Biblicum Franciscanum]], and [[Seabury-Western Theological Seminary]]. He has served on the editorial board of [[The Bible Today]] and [[Old Testament Abstracts]], previously being the general editor of the former.
==Education==
Hoppe first received his M.A. in Theology from the [[Aquinas Institute of Theology]] and then went on to receive a Ph.D. in Religion from [[Northwestern University]].<ref name=CTUprofile />
== Career ==
Hoppe joined and has been on the faculty of Catholic Theological Union (CTU) since 1981. Since then, he has authored many books on the Old Testament and [[biblical archaeology]] and has served in many archaeological projects in [[Upper Galilee]] as well as being the director of the fall study program of CTU in [[Jerusalem]] and lead its first Holy Land Pilgrimage.<ref>Registration deadline for Holy Land pilgrimage extended to Oct. 6, ''US Catholic Magazine''. Retrieved 21 August 2018. [https://www.uscatholic.org/HolyLand2015 Link]</ref> He has written a number of scholarly articles and books, including ''The Holy City: Jerusalem in the Theology of the Old Testament'' (2000) and was one of the archaeologists to work on the hypothesis of a [[House of Peter]] at [[Capernaum]].<ref>Meier, John P. A Marginal Jew: Rethinking the Historical Jesus, Volume V: Probing the Authenticity of the Parables. Yale University Press, 2009: pg. 330.</ref> He has written for [[America (magazine)|America Magazine]]<ref>[https://www.americamagazine.org/issue/culture/gospel-truth/ The Gospel Truth]. Retrieved 21 August 2018.</ref> and has outlined his views on the Bible in an interview with US Catholic magazine.<ref>[https://www.uscatholic.org/HoppeInterview/ A primer on the Old Testament]. Retrieved 21 August 2018.</ref> He has been noted by the [[National Catholic Register]] for his support of the [[Dei verbum]] to Catholic life and scripture,<ref>[http://www.ncregister.com/daily-news/dei-verbum-moved-the-bible-to-the-center-of-catholic-life/ ‘Dei Verbum’ ‘Moved the Bible to the Center of Catholic Life’]</ref> and believes the question of archaeology is separate from belief in the [[Bible]].<ref>Fiensy, David A. Insights from Archaeology. Fortress Press, 2017: pg. 31.</ref>

(Paulist Press 1984) *''Deuteronomy'' (1985) *''Being Poor: A Biblical Study'' (1987). *''A New Heart: A Commentary on the Book of Ezekiel'' (Eerdmans 1991). *''The synagogues and churches of ancient Palestine'' (1994) *''A guide to the lands of the Bible'' (1999) *''The Holy City: Jerusalem in the Theology of the Old Testament'' (2000). *''A Retreat with Matthew: Going Beyond the Law'' (2000). *''There shall be no poor among you: Poverty in the Bible'' (Abingdon Press 2004). *''New Light from Old Stories: Hebrew Scriptures for Today’s World'' (2005) *''Priests, Prophets, and Sages: Catholic Perspectives on the Old Testament'' (2006). *''Caesarea Maritima'' (Oxford 2013) *''The Book of Isaiah: The Fifth Gospel'' (2016).

The '''Master of Performing Arts''' ('''M.P.A.''' or '''M.Perf.A.''') is a [[graduate degree]] awarded in the fields of [[dance]], [[drama]], [[film]] and [[music]]. The degree generally requires a minimum of two years of full-time study to complete.<ref name="Post-Graduate Programmes">{{cite web |url=http://www.bdu.ac.in/academic.php |title=Post-Graduate Programmes |author=Bharathidasan University |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref> The degree program is offered primarily in Asia,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Unesco. Principal Regional Office for Asia and the Pacific|author2=Regional Institute of Higher Education and Development|title=Handbook on diplomas, degrees and other certificates granted by higher education Institutions in Asia and the Pacific|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XUcmAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=28 November 2012|year=1998|publisher=SEAMEO Regional Centre for Higher Education and Development|isbn=978-974-202-036-1|page=115}}</ref> and was formerly offered in the United States of America,<ref>{{cite book|author1=James Cass|author2=Max Birnbaum|title=Comparative Guide to American Colleges for Students, Parents, and Counselors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LYNMAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=28 November 2012|year=1983|publisher=Harper & Row|page=xii}}</ref> where it has been supplanted by the more prevalent [[Master of Fine Arts]], [[Master of Music]] and [[Master of Arts]] in Performing Arts degrees.
== Asia ==
Institutions presently offering a Master of Performing Arts program include:
=== Bangladesh ===
*[[Rajshahi University]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tmusicru.blogspot.com/ |title=Department of Theatre and Music |author=Rajshahi University |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref>
=== India ===
*[[Dr. Hari Singh Gour University]]<ref>http://www.dhsgsu.ac.in</ref> *[[Banaras Hindu University]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bhu.ac.in/fpa/Course%20offered.htm |title=Course Offered |author=Banaras Hindu University |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref> *[[Bhatkhande Music Institute]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bhatkhandemusic.edu.in/pages/courses.html |title=Courses and Schemes |author=Bhatkhande Music Institute |accessdate=30 November 2012}}</ref> *[[Bharathidasan University]]<ref name="Post-Graduate Programmes" /> *[[Indira Gandhi National Open University]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ignou.ac.in/ignou/aboutignou/school/sopva/programmes/detail/297/1 |title=School of Performing and Visual Arts Programmes |author=Indira Gandhi National Open University |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref> *[[Lovely Professional University]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lpu.in/program/MPA-Master-of-Performing-Arts.php |title=Programme Details |author=Lovely Professional University |accessdate=28 November 2012}} </ref> *[[University of Hyderabad]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uohyd.ac.in/index.php/academics/2011-10-27-18-38-04/sarojini-naidu-school-of-arts-a-communication/dept-dance/programmes-of-study |title=Programmes of Study |author=University of Hyderabad |accessdate=28 November 2012}} </ref>
=== Malaysia ===
*[[University of Malaya]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ips.um.edu.my/images/ips/doc/admission/iklan_web_sem_2,_20112012.pdf |title=Programmes for Semester II (February) 2011/2012 Session |author=University of Malaya |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref>
== Europe ==
=== Italy ===
In the Italian higher education system, the various [[:it:Accademia di belle arti|Academies of Fine Arts]] offer second level programs that lead to a "[[:it:Diploma accademico|Diploma Accademico]] di Secondo Livello in Arti Visive e Discipline dello Spettacolo" which translates to "Masters in Visual and Performing Arts". The degree bears this name regardless of whether the discipline studied was in the Visual Arts or the Performing Arts. This credential is thus equivalent if the discipline studied was a Performing Arts discipline.
== United States of America ==
Institutions that formerly granted the Master of Performing Arts degree include:
=== California===
*[[University of Southern California]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fpcmv.org/Recital_Musician_Notes.pdf |title=A Musical Recital |author=First Presbyterian Church of Mountain View |accessdate=30 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Louisiana ===
*[[University of New Orleans]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tulane.edu/liberal-arts/music/aigerim-magavina.cfm |title=Aigerim Magavina |author=Tulane University |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Massachusetts ===
*[[Emerson College]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wheelock.edu/giving/passion-for-action/linda-nathan |title=2011 Passion for Action Leadership Award Recipient |author=Wheelock College |accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Oklahoma ===
*[[Oklahoma City University]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.okcu.edu/focus/fall2002/28-32.pdf |title=Through the Years |author=Oklahoma City University |accessdate=28 November 2012}} </ref>

An '''Measured Environmental Concentration (MEC)''' relates to a chemical substance found in an environmental sample. The concentration of the compound may result from direct contamination, transformation and/or metabolization of a different chemical contaminant, natural origin or a combination of these sources.
MEC is to be used as a reference in the context of [[Chemical Safety Assessment]]s (CSA) and should be compared with the respective [[Predicted Environmental Concentration]] (PEC) and [[Predicted No-Effect Concentration]] (PNEC) in order to decide whether exposure model is valid and the compound related risk is controlled.

{{other uses|Mystery Train (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox book | name = Mystery Train | border = yes | image = Mystery_Train_book_cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Greil Marcus]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = Paul May | country = United States | language = English | genre = [[Music criticism]]
[[Social history]] | published = 1st edition: 1975
6th edition: 2015 | publisher = 1st edition: [[E. P. Dutton]]
5th edition: [[Plume (publisher)|Plume]] | media_type = paperback book | pages = | isbn = 978-0452289185 | oclc = }} '''''Mystery Train: Images of America in Rock 'N' Roll Music''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book written in 1975 by [[Greil Marcus]]. It features critical essays centered around artists such as [[Elvis Presley]], [[Sly Stone]], [[Robert Johnson]], and [[Randy Newman]]. ==Authorship== [[Greil Marcus]], rock critic and columnist for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', and contributor to other publications, such as ''[[Creem]]'', the ''[[The Village Voice|Village Voice]]'', and ''[[Artforum]]'', wrote ''Mystery Train'' in 1975. In the prologue, he relates that the book "is no attempt at synthesis, but a recognition of unities in the American imagination that already exist."Marcus (1975) The writing, according to the author, took about "two years of doing nothing else."Sheffield (2015) ''Mystery Train'', according to one reviewer, reflects on what could be called "the historical turn" that rock took at the close of the [[1960s in music|60s]], initiated by [[Bob Dylan]] and [[the Band]], and followed through by everyone from [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]] to [[Randy Newman]], the music moving "beyond rock'n'roll's teenage immersion in the present to an adult sophistication steeped in deep knowledge of rock's roots in blues and country and lyrics that likewise looked to the past for inspiration."Reynolds (2012) According to another reviewer, Marcus proceeds in his examination of American popular culture with the "democratic assumption" that Presley and [[Herman Melville]] are already cultural and political equals, and are, therefore, "in conversation with one another - having a dialogue about freedom and limits, innovation and tradition, American dreams and American obsessions."Cantwell (2015) When the 2nd edition came out, Elvis had recently died, and Marcus was asked to amend the chapter relating to Elvis by putting everything in the [[past tense]] but he refused, because, he said, "Elvis' presence was so powerful, I felt he's always in the [[present tense]]."Sheffield (2015) ''Mystery Train'' opens with an episode on the ''[[Dick Cavett show]]'', where [[Little Richard]] interrupts a disagreement between a writer and a critic, and closes with a [[Transcription (linguistics)|transcript]] of [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] arguing with producer [[Sam Phillips]] as they are setting up to record "[[Great Balls of Fire]]" in 1957.Marcus (1975). ==Critical reception== [[Frank Rich]] reviewed the book for ''[[The Village Voice]]'' and wrote that Marcus' "frame of reference is so vast that he never runs out of connections worth making between the music he loves and just about anything else that matters in American art and life.” [[David Itzkoff]] and [[Alan Light]], in a 2005 critical roundup of music-related books, claimed that ''Myster Train'' is "perhaps the finest book ever written about pop music."Itzkoff, Light (2005) ''[[New York Times]]'' literary critic [[Dwight Garner (critic)|Dwight Garner]] stated in 2015 that "most critics and serious listeners think [''Mystery Train'']’s almost certainly the best book yet written about American music in general, and about rock in particular."Garner (2015) In 2011, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine picked it among the "100 best and most influential [books] written in English since 1923."''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' (2011) ==List of contents== *Author's note *PROLOGUE *ANCESTORS :*[[Harmonica Frank|HARMONICA FRANK]] :*[[Robert Johnson|ROBERT JOHNSON]] *INHERITORS :*[[The Band|THE BAND]]: Pilgrims' Progress ::''Crossing the Border / Stranger Blues / The Righteous Land / Even Stranger Blues / The Weight'' :*[[Sly Stone|SLY STONE]]: The Myth of Staggerlee ::''Staggerlee / Sly Stone / Riot / Sly Versus Superfly / A Quiet Rebellion'' :*[[Randy Newman|RANDY NEWMAN]]: Every Man Is Free ::''Pop / Newman's America, 1 / Newman's America, 2 / Newman's Failure'' :*[[Elvis Presley|ELVIS]]: Presliad ::''Fanfare / Hillbilly Music / Raised Up / The Rockabilly Moment / Elvis Moves Out / The Boy Who Stole The Blues / The Pink Cadillac / Elvis At Home / Mystery Train / Finale'' *EPILOGUE *NOTES AND DISCOGRAPHIES ==Similar works by the author== *''[[Dead Elvis (book)|Dead Elvis]]'' (1991), on the influence of Elvis Presley on [[American culture]] in the latter half of the [[1970s in music|1970s]]. *''[[Invisible Republic]]'' (1997), on the creation and cultural importance of ''[[The Basement Tapes]]'', a series of recordings made by [[Bob Dylan]] in 1967 in collaboration with the Hawks, who would subsequently become known as [[the Band]]. ==See also== *[[Music journalism]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *Cantwell, David. "[http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/greil-marcuss-critical-super-power?intcid=mod-latest Greil Marcus's Critical Super Power]", ''[[The New Yorker]]'', 2 December 2015 *Garner, Dwight. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/03/books/just-a-book-no-more-like-a-trusty-companion.html?_r=0 Just a Book? No, More Like a Trusty Companion]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 2 September 2015 *Itzkoff, David & Alan Light. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/03/books/review/music-chronicle.html Music Chronicle]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', 3 July 2005 *Marcus, Greil. ''Mystery Train: Images of America in Rock 'N' Roll Music''; Omnibus; London; 1975 {{ISBN|0860013111}} *Reynolds, Simon. "[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/feb/17/greil-marcus-life-in-writing Greil Marcus: a life in writing]", ''[[The Guardian]]'', 17 February 2012 *Sheffield, Rob. "[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/a-conversation-with-greil-marcus-mystery-train-keeps-rolling-at-40-20151019#ixzz4D3LgVITa A Conversation With Greil Marcus: 'Mystery Train' Keeps Rolling at 40]", ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', 19 October 2015 *[http://entertainment.time.com/2011/08/30/all-time-100-best-nonfiction-books/slide/mystery-train-by-greil-marcus/ All-TIME 100 Nonfiction Books]", ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, 17 August 2011 ==External links== *[[Adam Mars-Jones|Mars-Jones, Adam]]. "[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/dec/20/a-new-literary-history-america A New Literary History of America Edited by Greil Marcus and Werner Sollors], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 31 January 2010 [[Category:Music criticism]] [[Category:Social history of the United States]] [[Category:Rock and roll]] [[Category:Books about Elvis Presley]] [[Category:Americana]] [[Category:1975 books]] [[Category:English-language books]] [[Category:E. P. Dutton books]]

{{Infobox organization |image = NHDLogo R BlkPMS185 v2 web.jpg |caption = |motto = It's more than a day, it's an Experience. |formation = 1974 |extinction = |type = Nonprofit Organization, Competition |status = Active |purpose = To promote the study and appreciation of history among students. |headquarters = [[University of Maryland, College Park]] |language = English |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Dr. Cathy Gorn |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = [http://www.aaslh.org/ American Association for State and Local History], [[American Historical Association]], [http://www.statehumanities.org/ Federation of State Humanities Councils], [[National Association of Secondary School Principals]], [http://nchs.ucla.edu/ National Center for History in the Schools], [[National Council for History Education]], [[National Council for the Social Studies]], [[Organization of American Historians]], [[Society of American Archivists]] |budget = |remarks = |name = National History Day |size = 90px |abbreviation = NHD |location = Maryland |region_served = [[United States of America]] |membership = 500,000 students, 30,000 teachers per year |num_staff =10 |num_volunteers = |website = {{URL|http://www.nhd.org}} }}
'''National History Day''' is non-profit organization based in [[College Park, Maryland]] that operates an annual project-based contest for students in grades 6-12. It has affiliates in all fifty states, Washington, D.C., [[Puerto Rico]], [[Guam]], [[American Samoa]], South Korea, China, South Asia, and Central America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nhd.org/affiliates|title=Affiliates {{!}} National History Day {{!}} NHD|website=nhd.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref> It started as a local program in Cleveland, Ohio, headed by Dr. David Van Tassell, a history professor at [[Case Western Reserve University]].<ref>Gorn, 2001</ref> It grew from 129 students in 1974 to over 500,000 students in 48 states in 1991, and 700,000 students and 40,000 teachers in 2001.<ref>Page (1992)</ref><ref>Gorn (2001)</ref> Today more than half a million students enter through local contests. They construct entries as an individual or a group in one of five categories: Documentary, Exhibit, Paper, Performance or Website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhd.org/categories|title=Categories|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Nhd.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2012-12-27}}</ref> Students then compete in a series of regional contests with top entries advancing to state/affiliate contests. The top two entries in each category and division are invited to compete at the National Contest.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nhd.org/how-enter-contest|title=How to {{!}} National History Day {{!}} NHD|website=nhd.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref>
==History of the National History Day Contest== The contest started in Cleveland in 1974.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nhd.org/about|title=National History Day {{!}} NHD|website=nhd.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref> Members of the History Department at [[Case Western Reserve University]] developed the initial idea for a history contest akin to Science Fair. Students gathered on campus to devote one day to history calling it "National History Day." Over the next few years, the contest expanded throughout Ohio and into surrounding Midwestern states. By 1980, with the help of the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]], National History Day had grown into a national non-profit organization and in 1992 National History Day moved its headquarters from Cleveland to the Washington, D.C., area. National History Day now runs multiple educational programs but the National Contest is still the largest of these. The national finals take place each June during a week-long event held at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]].<ref>Byers, David. "Four score and seven years ago... Costumed history buffs hit campus in national competition." The Diamondback Online 15 June 2006: 1-1.</ref>
==National History Day Contest Annual Theme== The annual theme is usually a phrase ending with "in history" and is often an alliteration, such as, "Revolution, Reaction, Reform in History." The theme frames students’ research within a historical theme. The theme is chosen for the broad application to world, national, or state history and its relevance to ancient history or to the more recent past. The 2018 theme was ''Conflict and Compromise in History,'' and the 2019 theme is ''Triumph and Tragedy in History''. "The intentional selection of the theme for the National History Day Contest is to provide an opportunity for students to push past the antiquated view of history as mere facts and dates and drill down into historical content to develop perspective and understanding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nhd.org/node/542|title=Taking A Stand in History {{!}} National History Day {{!}} NHD|website=nhd.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref>" Themes are rotated each year and prior themes are often used after approximately seven years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nhd.org/previous-annual-themes|title=National History Day {{!}} NHD|website=www.nhd.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref>
==Competition==
===Judging=== National History Day participants are judged on three deciding factors: Historical Quality, Relation to Theme, and Clarity of Presentation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhd.org/national-contest-judges%E2%80%99-information|title=National History Day | Classroom Connection|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Nhd.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2012-12-27}}</ref> Research should include primary and secondary sources. Additionally, sources need to be clearly cited with the inclusion of an annotated bibliography. <ref>https://www.nhd.org/annotated-bibliography</ref> There is also a required process paper that needs to be included with the project, describing your process and struggles in creating an NHD project. <ref>https://www.nhd.org/annotated-bibliography</ref>
===State and Regional Competitions=== In some regions, students who reach enough points in their judging advance to states, and any number of students at regional competitions can advance to states. In other states, such as California, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania, the top three projects at the regional competition advance to the state competition. Regions can be divided by geographic area, population, or by county.
At the state/affiliate level contests, students compete for a variety of prizes. The top two entries in each category and division are invited to the National Contest held each June at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]].
===National Competition=== ====Preliminaries==== In the preliminary rounds, each entry presents their project before a panel of three judges. In the case of the paper and website categories, the projects have been reviewed by the judges prior to the presentations. Performances, documentaries, and exhibits are presented for the judges for the first time at the contest. The top entry in each judging group advances to the final round, called "Run Offs."
====Finals==== Those in the performance and documentary categories are notified they advanced to the final round and then present their work to a panel of three new judges. Those in the paper, website, and exhibit categories are not informed if they have made it into the final round. Their projects are judged by a panel of three new judges, but the students are not interviewed in this round. Their project then has to stand alone for the final judging.
[[File:Scans0012.jpg|thumb|National History Day Medal: 2005-2006|200px|right|Example of a National History Day Medal]] The awards for first, second, and third place at the national level are $1000, $500, and $250, respectively. "Outstanding Entry" awards are also given to two projects from each state: one junior entry and one senior entry. There are also more than a dozen special prizes awarded worth between $250 and $2,500.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nhd.org/special-prizes|title=National History Day {{!}} NHD|website=www.nhd.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-02}}</ref>
==== Impact on students ==== An independent study conducted in 2011 demonstrated that students who participate in the National History Day Contest outperform their non-participating peers and score higher on standardized tests, although this might be a reflection on the type of students who choose to participate in National History Day - those who seek to challenge themselves.<ref>"[http://www.navyhistory.org/2012/07/alaska-students-awarded-nhf-national-history-day-prize/ Three Alaska Students Awarded NHF National History Day Prize]." ''Naval Historical Foundation,'' 17 July 2012. Accessed 10 Feb. 2013.</ref>
===Impact on historians=== Arnita Jones, executive director of the [[American Historical Association]], wrote in 2001: :Perhaps the greatest impact of National History Day...was on the historical profession itself. I truly believe that never have so many historians enjoyed engaging in the pursuit of history outside their offices, their regular classrooms, and their academic research as have the thousands who have participated in National History Day as teachers, mentors, consultants and judges over more than two decades.<ref>Quoted in Gorn (2001)</ref>
==See also== *[[Science Fair]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Adams, David Wallace, and Marvin Pasch. "The past as experience: A qualitative assessment of National History Day." ''[[History Teacher]]'' (1987) 20#2: 179-194. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/493027 in JSTOR] * Fehn, Bruce R.; Schul, James E. "Teaching and Learning Competent Historical Documentary Making: Lessons from National History Day Winners," ''History Teacher'' (2011) 45#1 pp 25–42. [http://www.societyforhistoryeducation.org/pdfs/Fehn_and_Schul.pdf online] * Gorn, Cathy. "A Tribute to a Founding Father: David Van Tassel and National History Day," ''History Teacher'' (2001) 34#2 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3054281 in JSTOR] * Page, Marilyn Louise. "National history day: An ethnohistorical case study." (PhD dissertation, U of Massachusetts-Amherst, 1992). [http://scholarworks.umass.edu/dissertations/AAI9305878/ online] * Taber-Conover, Rebecca, "History Day in Connecticut," ''Connecticut History'' (2012) 51#2 pp 261–264

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Stuffed animal modified for sexual use.jpg|thumb|A stuffed animal modified for sexual use.]] --> '''Plushophilia''' (from "[[Stuffed toy|plushie]]" and "[[-phil-|-philia]]") is a [[paraphilia]] involving [[stuffed animals]]. Most plushophiles modify their [[plushies]] with a hole or holes reminiscent of those found in sex toys, to allow them to sexually interact with their plushies. Plushophiles are sometimes called ''plushies'', although this term (plushies) can also refer to non-sexual stuffed animal enthusiasts, and to stuffed animals in general.<ref>{{Citation|last = Hill|first = Dave|title = Cuddle Time|newspaper = [[Salon.com]]|date = 2000-06-19|url = http://archive.salon.com/sex/feature/2000/06/19/plushies/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jun/04/news/cl-6207 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Once Seen as Taboos, Sexual Fetishes Are Gaining Acceptance | first=Kathleen | last=Kelleher | date=2001-06-04 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref>
==Popular plushies for plushophiles== *[[Ponies]] – a plush in a pony form, a cartoon from [[My Little Pony]]. *[[Wolf]] – a plush in a wolf form. *[[Jaguar]] – a plush in a jaguar form. *[[Tiger]] – a plush in a tiger form. *[[Bears]] – a large plush in a bear form.
== Furry fandom == Plushophilia is sometimes assumed to be a practice common within [[furry fandom]], due in part to a 2001 article by ''Vanity Fair'' that linked various members of the furry community with plushophilia.<ref>{{cite web|author=Craig Malisow |url=http://www.houstonpress.com/2003-12-18/news/wild-kingdom/ |title=Wild Kingdom |publisher=Houston Press |date=2003-12-18 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/2001/041201/cover.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020830043412/http://www.montrealmirror.com/ARCHIVES/2001/041201/cover.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 30, 2002 |accessdate=November 15, 2009 |df= |title=Montreal's furries and furverts defend their unusual lifestyle}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Kates |first=Tasha |url=http://citypaper.net/articles/2004-07-08/cb2.shtml |title=Animal Magnetism |publisher=Citypaper.net |date= |accessdate=2013-04-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713170850/http://citypaper.net/articles/2004-07-08/cb2.shtml |archivedate=2015-07-13 |df= }}</ref><ref name="pittsburgh_city"> {{Citation | last = Meinzer | first = Melissa | title = Animal Passions | newspaper = [[Pittsburgh City Paper]]
| date = 2006-06-29 | url = http://www.pittsburghcitypaper.ws/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A28606}} </ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Gurley | first = George | title = Pleasures of the Fur | newspaper = [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]
| date = March 2001 | url = http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2001/03/furries200103}} </ref> A 1998 survey of 360 members of the furry community suggested less than one percent (that is, fewer than four people) attested to being plushophiles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.visi.com/~phantos/furrysoc.html |title=The Darken Hollow - Thoughts - Furry Sociology |publisher=Visi.com |date=2002-08-01 |accessdate=2013-04-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061015191107/http://www.visi.com/~phantos/furrysoc.html |archivedate=2006-10-15 |df= }}</ref>
Pornography and sexual activity involving [[anthropomorphism|animal anthropomorphism]] (including plushophilia and paraphilias involving [[fursuit]]s and [[cartoon animal]]s) is known in the furry fandom community as "[[Furry fandom#Sexual aspects|yiff]]" (and sexual acts as "yiffing").<ref name="pittsburgh_city"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/8355287.stm | work=BBC News | title=Who are the furries? | date=2009-11-13 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref>
== Being in another form == [[Anne Lawrence]] has proposed that sexual arousal that depends upon imagining one's self as plush or "representations of anthropomorphic animal characters in [[animated cartoon]]s" be termed '''autoplushophilia'''.<ref name=lawrence>Lawrence, A. A. (2009). Erotic target location errors: An under appreciated paraphilic dimension. ''The Journal of Sex Research, 46,'' 194-215.</ref> Paraphilic interests that involve being in another form have been referred to as [[erotic target location error]]s.
